If bones could scream, a bloodcurdling din would be reverberating through a 500-year-old cemetery in Peru. Human skeletons unearthed there have yielded the first direct evidence of Inca fatalities caused by Spanish conquerors.
 
 European newcomers killed some Inca individuals with guns, steel lances or hammers, and possibly light cannons, scientists report online in the March 23 American Journal of Physical Anthropology.
 
 Surprisingly, though, no incisions or other marks characteristic of sword injuries appear on these bones, according to a team led by archaeologist Guillermo XXXX of the Consult on Cultural Heritage in Lima and including anthropologist Melissa Murphy of the University of Wyoming in Laramie. Spanish documents from the 16th century emphasize steel swords as a favored military weapon.

 Inca Cemetery Holds Brutal Glimpses Of Spanish Violence - Science News

In 1910, the British government asked Roger Casement, a consular official, to investigate reports that a British registered company was exploiting Barbadian workers in the Amazon. Intrepid and resourceful, Casement gathered testimonies about the armed extortion and debt bondage that supported the rubber trade. Back in London, he championed the rights of the Barbadian migrants as well as those of the indigenous Indians, tens of thousands of whom had died harvesting wild rubber for their British masters.

 Maybe I misunderstood your post here, but if they're performing human sacrifice on their own children on a regular basis, don't you think at some point the view that they need to be civilized may actually have some merit?? After all, if a commune of people were doing this in modern times near where you live, would you not want them to be taken over and stopped? Sometimes a culture really can be harmful to the point that it needs to be conquered. Look at the Nazis, for instance--it's a good thing THEY were taken over and stopped. It may not be politically correct to condone the conquering of such a group, but sometimes it's the truth. 
 I remember in school always hearing the conquistadors made out to be the evil people, but was never taught about the atrocities the INCAS were doing on their children until I did my own research. IMO, this is all a perfect example of liberal values having influenced a generation of people in schools: the idea that conquering is always bad, and the conquerors are always the bad guys no matter what, and avoiding the details that show things are not always so simple as they seem. 
 Plus, the 'noble savage' ideal has become so prevalent that people don't realize it inadvertently colors their view of other cultures and makes them overlook cultural and moral atrocities they would never overlook otherwise or in their own society.
 None of that is to say that the conquistadors were good. They were largelt motivated by greed, after all. But we also need to at least acknowledge that the Incas weren't just some group of innocent victims; they were doing some horrible, horrible things to their own children to the level that we would call a holocaust in today's time. Please, get the facts of both sides and think for yourself rather than just taking the standard left-leaning anti-imperialist spoonfeeding at the cost of making up your own mind.

 I never said Inca culture was good and European culture was evil, and I never said that the Incas were the good guys. But, the Spanish were definitely the bad guys. The took something that belonged to someone else, and they raped, murdered, stole, and pillaged while they did it. They committed crimes on a people who did nothing to harm them. While we abhor human sacrifices, they viewed it as perfectly normal. From the outside, many of our practices could be viewed as barbaric, evil, murderous, and uncivil, but that doesn't give anyone the right to invade us.
